titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Brand Whitlock papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Theresa Berger

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-03-06T09:05-0800
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Materials rehoused and inventory created by Theresa Berger.

physdesc.extent: 9 manuscript boxes, 4 oversize boxes, 1 oversize folder

did.abstract: Writings, diaries, scrapbooks, drawings, printed matter, and photographs relating to Belgian-American relations during World War I, the work of the Commission for Relief in Belgium, and the writings of Brand Whitlock.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Brand Whitlock papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1953.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the library catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Brand Whitlock was an American author, politician, diplomat, and ambassador to Belgium from 1913 to 1922. After serving as mayor of Toledo, Ohio from 1906 to 1913, Whitlock was appointed ambassador to Belgium by President Woodrow Wilson in 1913. In 1914, Whitlock's diplomatic duties increased significantly when the outbreak of the First World War and subsequent German occupation of Belgium put him in charge of various relief efforts for Belgian citizens. Whitlock's efforts to ensure that food sent by the Committee for Relief in Belgium went directly to Belgian citizens and not German forces, as well as his frequent appeals to German military authorities on behalf of condemned prisoners in Belgium, earned him the nickname Le Ministre Protecteur. In addition to his diplomatic and political efforts, Whitlock published several novels, biographies, articles, and short essays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Brand Whitlock papers consist of writings, diaries, photographs, albums, scrapbooks, drawings, illustrations, and printed matter relating to Belgian-American relations during World War I, the work of the Commission for Relief in Belgium, and the numerous writings of Brand Whitlock. Several of the writings in the collection appear to be unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, articles, certificates, receipts, and other material related to Whitlock's diplomatic and literary careers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes news clippings and magazine features about Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a social ledger describing calls made to the American Embassy in Belgium, possibly owned by Whitlock, his wife (Mrs. Whitlock), his mother (also Mrs. Whitlock), or his mother-in-law (Mrs. Brainerd).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Whitlock's bookplates, hotel receipts, and a program for a banquet held in Washington, D.C. in 1928 honoring the King and Queen of Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes additional magazine features about Whitlock (Box 12) as well as a bound certificate of recognition presented to Whitlock on behalf of the Belgian government (Box 13).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains edited manuscripts, notes, prints, and drafts relating to various published and unpublished writings by Whitlock.

did.unittitle: "The American Quality in American Literature: A Paper to Be Read Before the National Institute of Arts and Letters,"
"The City of the Future," address delivered at The Hudson Theatre,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The novel was published one chapter at a time in The Delineator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relates to an unpublished biography of Thomas Jefferson.

did.unittitle: Manuscript addressed to Miss Mary Chaldecott,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes various photos of Colonial Williamsburg dated 1933.

did.unittitle: "The Law of the Land," Atlantic Monthly,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes manuscript excerpts, as well as an assumed manuscript addressed to Miss Mary Chaldecott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes published versions and reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes drafts, edits, and incomplete manuscripts of works with possible titles such as "The Game" and "A Lincoln Penny." Also includes possible excerpts from The Buckeyes and Walt Whitman: How to Know Him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes various manuscripts, chapter excerpts, and notes for an unfinished novel.

did.unittitle: "Progress and [?] in Glasgow," notes and drafts,
"The Rehabilitation of General Todhunter," Sunday Magazine,
"The Sofa: How a Grave Political Crisis Yielded to Feminine Tact," The Argosy,
"A Son of a Good-For-Nothing: A Satirical Comedy in Four Acts," by Brand Whitlock and Frank Neilson, manuscript,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes related correspondence.

did.unittitle: The Stranger on the Island (also known as "Beaver Island"),
Manuscript addressed to Miss Mary Chaldecott,
Manuscript addressed to Miss Agnes F. Pearson,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It is not certain that these pages are part of The Stranger on the Island ("Beaver Island").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes typed manuscript with edits, as well as a folder titled "Notes for the Countess of Granvallon," the novel's original title.

did.unittitle: "The White Slave in America," The English Review,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains pages of an untitled manuscript, possibly Whitlock's biography of Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains notes and pages related to an untitled manuscript, possibly J. Hardin and Son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains letters and notes of gratitude from Belgian children, teachers, and citizens, as well as some business-related correspondence. Several letters include children's artwork. Material in English, French, and Flemish

did.unittitle: Baron Eugène de Moffarts, et. al,
Book of notes from Belgian citizens,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains notes from Belgian citizens expressing their gratitude towards relief efforts conducted by the United States.

did.unittitle: Commission for Relief in Belgium / Lace Department of the Commission for Relief in Belgium,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, notes, and receipts addressed to Brand Whitlock and Mrs. Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains letters of gratitude from Belgian school teachers and citizens thanking Whitlock and the Commission for Relief in Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains letters from children in Brussels thanking Whitlock for his relief efforts in Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains two unidentified journals, as well as collected poems by Witter Bynner and A. E. Houseman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Possibly written by Whitlock's mother-in-law (Mrs. Brainerd), his wife (Mrs. Whitlock), or his mother (also Mrs. Whitlock). The journals describe life and events in Belgium in 1914.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains two untitled scrapbooks, one with war-related clippings, the other with cartoons and illustrations pasted together to create humorous scenes depicting social and political commentary on current events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains prints, autographed portraits, and a photo album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes autographed portraits of European leaders and diplomats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes an album with photos of Whitlock, his family, and several unidentified people, presumably from the family's time in Belgium. Folder 8 : 19 contains loose photographs from the album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains various prints and mounted portraits. Subjects include Brand Whitlock and family, the American Embassy in Belgium, local sculptures and artwork, and portraits of European military and political figures, many with signatures and inscriptions addressed to Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains sketches, illustrations, and watercolors, some with artists' signatures and dedications to Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains prints of portrait sketches of European officials by H. Lemaire in original foldering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes sketches and watercolor paintings of military figures, some with artists' signatures and inscriptions to Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a printed map of Brussels with various landmarks identified by hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a collection of watercolor paintings by F. Houget depicting Belgian officials and politicians playing golf. Includes the artist's signature and an inscription to Whitlock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes sketches dedicated to Whitlock by A. Baertsoen and two unknown artists. The map case contains a large sketch entitled "La Resistance," depicting what appears to be Lady Liberty warding off a black bird, as well as a sketch by A. Baertsoen depicting a snow-covered village in Belgium (1921).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, articles, sheet music, postcards, and other material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings, articles, theater programs, and other material related to popular works of literature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes clippings, conference proceedings, newspapers, magazines, postcards, travel brochures, and other material. Subjects include European travel, Cannes, Belgium, and the war from 1914-1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes magazines, newspapers, event programs, and sheet music in French and English.
